target.translation[0].definitions[0].def: something that you are trying to achieve, such as a total, an amount, or a time
target.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: There is no target date for completion of the new project.
The government may fail to meet (=achieve) its  target of recycling 25% of domestic waste.
Jiang set annual growth targets of 8–9%.
the target of a one-third reduction in road accidents
Higher degrees in English are a target for foreign students.
The company says that growth of 10% is on target.
target.translation[0].definitions[1].def: an object, person, or place that is deliberately chosen to be attacked
target.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: Cars without security devices are an easy target for the thief.
Railway stations are prime targets (=very likely targets) for bombs.
target.translation[0].definitions[2].def: the person or place that is most directly affected by an action, especially a bad one
target.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: The area has become a prime target for supermarket development.
The country is a target of criticism for its human rights record.
target.translation[0].definitions[3].def: something that you practise shooting at, especially a round board with circles on it
target.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: The area is used by the army for target practice.
target.translation[0].note_box[0].headin: – Meaning 1: something that you are trying to achieve, such as a total, an amount, or a time
target.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: The government wants to meet its target of building three million new homes by 2020.
They achieved their target with just days to spare.
The company has set ambitious business targets.
We have exceeded our target of £200,000.
Car production at the plant has fallen short of its target by 5%.
The targets they have set themselves are hugely ambitious.
The Kyoto Protocol set fairly modest targets for reductions in greenhouse gases.
The target is achievable, but only by hard work.
Both businesses exceeded their financial targets.
I’m confident we will meet our sales target by the end of the year.
The company’s growth targets have been achieved for the last three years.
There is no target date set for completion of the new project.
The government has set a target figure of 6.2%
target.translation[0].note_box[1].headin: – Meaning 2: an object, person, or place that is deliberately chosen to be attacked
target.translation[0].note_box[1].sectio: a prime target
Sporting events could become a prime target for terrorists.
the main target
The rebel-held town is one of the main targets for U S troops.
an easy/soft target
Some criminals now regard churches as easy targets.
a sitting target
In the open, the soldiers are sitting targets.
somebody’s intended target
The gunman missed his intended target.
a military target
The group insists that its bombs were directed against military targets.
a civilian target
The army denied it had attacked civilian targets.
a legitimate target
The rebels claimed that trains carrying soldiers are a legitimate target.
attack a target
They have attacked military targets such as army camps and airfields.
hit a target
Not every bomb hit its target.
miss a target
All of the missiles missed their target and no-one was killed.
target.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to make something have an effect on a particular limited group or area
target.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: The advertisement was designed to target a mass audience.
a new benefit targeted on low-income families
The programme is targeted at improving the health of women of all ages.
target.translation[1].definitions[1].def: to aim something at a target
target.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: The missiles are targeted at several key military sites.
target.translation[1].definitions[2].def: to choose a particular person or place to do something to, especially to attack them or criticize them
target.translation[1].definitions[2].exa: It’s clear that smaller, more vulnerable banks have been targeted.
He was targeted by terrorists for a second time last night.
target.translation[2].definitions[0].def: an organization, industry, government etc that is deliberately chosen to have something done to it
target.translation[2].definitions[0].exa: There was persistent speculation that the company could be the target of a takeover bid.
Computers are helping choose targets for direct-mail and telephone campaigns.
Europe will be the main target for rising South African coal exports.
target.translation[2].definitions[1].def: a result such as a total, an amount, or a time which you aim to achieve
target.translation[2].definitions[1].exa: Dealers are under pressure to meet sales targets.
Bonuses were introduced for employees who met production targets.
The federal funds rate slipped to 7% from its target level of 8%.
target.translation[2].definitions[2].def: on the way to achieving a result
target.translation[2].definitions[2].exa: The export business is booming and the U.S. business is right on target.
target.translation[2].definitions[3].def: a limited group of people or area that a plan, idea etc is aimed at
target.translation[2].definitions[3].exa: Who is the target audience for this book?
These advertisements are aimed mainly at our target customers.
target.translation[3].definitions[0].def: to aim products, programmes of work, etc at a particular area or group of people
target.translation[3].definitions[0].exa: We will target funds on areas of research where breakthroughs are imminent.
The booklet is targeted at people approaching retirement.
target.translation[3].definitions[1].def: to choose someone or something for a particular type of treatment
target.translation[3].definitions[1].exa: The main markets targeted for development have been those of the US and Western Europe.
